s.text: Recent work has shown that the genes responsible for embryonic induction of skeletal tissue are also involved in fracture healing.
Fracture is followed by four weeks of up-regulation of the stimulatory cytokines after fracture, and healing must take place within that window of time if it is to occur.
This may reflect a reduction in the number of osteogenic stem cells available for skeletal repair in older individuals [ 17].

In our earlier studies, comparable rats at one year of age failed to regain normal skeletal biomechanics within six months of femoral fracture, while younger rats regained normal biomechanics within four weeks after fracture [ 11].
In contrast, young rats achieved normal biomechanical strength by four weeks after fracture [ 12].
In contrast, young rats achieved normal biomechanical strength by four weeks after fracture [ 12].

In our earlier studies, comparable rats at one year of age failed to regain normal skeletal biomechanics within six months of femoral fracture, while younger rats regained normal biomechanics within four weeks after fracture [ 11].
In contrast, young rats achieved normal biomechanical strength by four weeks after fracture [ 12].
In contrast, young rats achieved normal biomechanical strength by four weeks after fracture [ 12].
The mRNA levels at four and six weeks after fracture were very low to undetectable in both groups (Fig.
In contrast, the type IA BMP receptor mRNA levels were detectable in the 0-time control younger rats, but not in the older rats (Fig.
Gene expression levels declined to undetectable levels at four and six weeks after fracture (Fig.
While the radiographic and histologic progression of fracture healing is well understood, there are less data on the cytokines that regulate and control the healing process at the cellular level.
It may suggest that there is a constant time of stimulation of cytokine production following injury, rather than negative feedback control over the process of fracture healing.
BMP-4 mRNA levels were also undetectable in the 0-time controls for both age groups (Fig.
Our results appear to violate the principle of negative feedback control over biological processes.
This decreased expression of bone-inductive genes prior to an adequate biological response suggests the absence of negative feedback regulation over fracture healing.
